hints.content:
Colleen has $\blueD{3}$ sons.

They ate $\greenD{18}$ total nuggets.

[[☃ image 1]]

What is the $\purpleC{\text{size of the groups}}$?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths. The first tape is labeled 18 and the second tape with 3 equal parts each labeled with a question mark. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the second tape is labeled with the words 3 equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}\times\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}= \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\blueD{3}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{18}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}=\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}$

So, $\greenD{18}\div \blueD{3}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many nuggets each son ate are:

 - $\blueD{3}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{18}$
 - $\greenD{18}\div \blueD{3}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

question.content:
Colleen made $18$ chicken nuggets for her $3$ sons.  Each son ate the same number of nuggets.  

**Which equations would help us find out how many nuggets each son ate?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
